title: Harvest Equipment and Container Safety
description: Requirements for harvest equipment and container cleanliness, maintenance, inspection procedures, and prevention of contamination from equipment and packaging materials

requirements.question: Are harvest containers maintained in good, clean condition and free from contamination?
requirements.automaticFailureReason: Contaminated or damaged harvest containers in direct contact with product create unacceptable food safety risk.

requirements.question: Are harvest containers protected from potential sources of contamination when not in use?
Are harvest containers of food-grade construction or materials?
Is harvest equipment inspected before use to ensure it is in good repair and adequately clean?
Are procedures in place to prevent use of containers or equipment for both product and non-food uses?
Are damaged harvest containers removed from service until repaired or replaced?

mandatoryStatements: Harvest containers must be maintained in good, clean condition and free from soil, debris, pests, or other contamination.
Containers must be protected from contamination when not in use through proper storage off the ground and protected from environmental exposure.
Harvest containers that directly contact product must be of food-grade construction or materials that do not contaminate product.
All harvest equipment must be inspected before use to ensure it is in good repair, adequately clean, and suitable for its intended purpose.
Containers and equipment must be dedicated to food use and not used interchangeably with non-food materials or chemicals.
capaInject: Establish a daily pre-use inspection protocol for harvest containers and equipment with acceptance criteria and reject procedures.
Designate clean container storage areas that are elevated off the ground, protected from weather, and segregated from contamination sources.
Implement a container identification or color-coding system to prevent mixing of product containers with chemical or non-food containers.
Develop a container maintenance and replacement program with criteria for removing damaged or contaminated containers from service.
Create sanitation schedules and procedures for harvest containers and equipment with monitoring and verification activities.
traceabilityInject: Maintain records of container and equipment inspections including date, inspector, items checked, deficiencies found, and actions taken.
Document container cleaning and sanitation activities including date, time, method, sanitizer used, and responsible person.
Keep records of containers or equipment removed from service including reason for removal, repair or disposal action, and return to service authorization.
Track procurement of new harvest containers including supplier, date, food-grade certification, and initial sanitation before use.
Log any product holds or investigations related to container or equipment contamination with full traceability to affected product lots.
micro_inject: Emphasize that harvest containers are in direct contact with product and can transfer pathogens if not properly cleaned and maintained.
Ensure containers are stored and handled to prevent accumulation of soil, water, or organic matter that could harbor pathogenic bacteria.
Implement protocols to prevent cross-contamination between dirty containers from previous use and clean product during harvest.
Verify that container materials and construction do not promote microbial growth or provide harborage for pathogens in cracks or crevices.
Monitor sanitation effectiveness of harvest containers through periodic microbiological swab testing of high-touch or product-contact surfaces.
